name: Warm French Goat's Cheese Salad (Salade de Chêvre Chaud)
description: Recipe video above. Warm Goat’s Cheese Salad is a classic starter found in bistros all across France. Called Salade de Chêvre Chaud, it's a fresh leaf salad with nuts and bacon, and crowned with pan-fried goat’s cheese medallions that are golden outside and oozing inside. Simple to make, this most French of French salads makes for a chic change from the usual crumbled goats cheese number!Serves 4 as a starter, or 2 as a meal
recipeIngredient: 2 x 60g / 2oz ripened goat's cheese (, each round 5-6cm (2-2.2") wide, ideally AOC (Note 1))
1/3 cup breadcrumbs (regular kind, else sub panko; (Note 2))
100g / 3.5oz  bacon (streaky; cut into 0.5 x 1.25cm (1/5 x 1/2") lardons)
1/2  head of red oak or bibb lettuce (large) (, washed, dried and leaves torn into 2 or 3 large pieces; (Note 3))
1 1/2 tbsp balsamic vinegar ((the best quality you can afford))
4 1/2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil ((the best quality you can afford))

itemListElement.text: Slice cheese: Cut goat's cheese if necessary to create ~ 1.25cm (1/2") thick rounds.
itemListElement.name: Slice cheese: Cut goat's cheese if necessary to create ~ 1.25cm (1/2") thick rounds.

itemListElement.text: Place flour, whisked egg and breadcrumbs in 3 separate, small bowls.
itemListElement.name: Place flour, whisked egg and breadcrumbs in 3 separate, small bowls.

itemListElement.text: Crumb cheese: Coat cheese in flour, shake off excess. Dip in egg, allow excess to drip. Coat with breadcrumbs, pressing to adhere. Place on plate and set aside.
itemListElement.name: Crumb cheese: Coat cheese in flour, shake off excess. Dip in egg, allow excess to drip. Coat with breadcrumbs, pressing to adhere. Place on plate and set aside.

itemListElement.text: Toast nuts: Spread nuts in a layer on a tray. Toast in a 180C / 375F oven for around 5 minutes until they are lightly browned and smell toasty. Immediately transfer to a small bowl to cool. Alternatively, toast in a skillet over medium heat (walnuts will take longer than pine nuts, so best to do in separate batches).
itemListElement.name: Toast nuts: Spread nuts in a layer on a tray. Toast in a 180C / 375F oven for around 5 minutes until they are lightly browned and smell toasty. Immediately transfer to a small bowl to cool. Alternatively, toast in a skillet over medium heat (walnuts will take longer than pine nuts, so best to do in separate batches).

itemListElement.text: Cook bacon: Place bacon in a cold non-stick pan. Turn the stove to medium and let the pan warm up. Once the fat starts to melt, turn the heat to high. Stir and cook bacon until golden. Drain excess fat on paper towels.
itemListElement.name: Cook bacon: Place bacon in a cold non-stick pan. Turn the stove to medium and let the pan warm up. Once the fat starts to melt, turn the heat to high. Stir and cook bacon until golden. Drain excess fat on paper towels.

itemListElement.text: Dressing: Shake dressing ingredients in a jar.
itemListElement.name: Dressing: Shake dressing ingredients in a jar.

itemListElement.text: Begin assembling salad: Place lettuce in a bowl, casually arrange tomatoes, then sprinkle with nuts and bacon.
itemListElement.name: Begin assembling salad: Place lettuce in a bowl, casually arrange tomatoes, then sprinkle with nuts and bacon.

itemListElement.text: Melt butter in a small non-stick pan over medium-high heat.
itemListElement.name: Melt butter in a small non-stick pan over medium-high heat.

itemListElement.text: Pan-fry cheese: Once butter is foaming, cook crumbed cheeses for 1 - 1 1/2 minutes on one side until golden. Carefully turn, cook other side for 1 minute until golden. Remove and drain on paper towels.
itemListElement.name: Pan-fry cheese: Once butter is foaming, cook crumbed cheeses for 1 - 1 1/2 minutes on one side until golden. Carefully turn, cook other side for 1 minute until golden. Remove and drain on paper towels.

itemListElement.text: Drizzle each salad with 2 tbsp of dressing. Arrange 2 crumbed cheeses on top of each salad. Sprinkle with chives.
itemListElement.name: Drizzle each salad with 2 tbsp of dressing. Arrange 2 crumbed cheeses on top of each salad. Sprinkle with chives.

itemListElement.text: Serve immediately, while cheese is hot and melty inside!

review.reviewBody: Fantastic recipe, very tasty. We had so much left over Goats cheese from Christmas that we had to end up freezing, this was a great way to finally use them up.
Looks 5* (though I haven't made it yet!) - I'd just like to ask first if the breaded cheeses can be kept for a day or two in the fridge before cooking?

It took some effort and time to make this dish exactly as instructed but it was so worth it! The flavours was incredible and looks absolutely stunning. My guests loved it too and were very impressed with the look and flavour of it. Highly recommend this recipe and will make it again.

My first bite of cheese was like eating a toasted marshmallow! crispy/toasted on the outside yet warm and gooey on the inside. Heaven! I could only get a soft’ish goats cheese, so like a previous person commented I kept the cheese in the fridge until just before breading and cooking to keep it as firm as possible. Worked perfectly :) thanks again for another spectacular recipe.

Made this with soft goat cheese. Sliced it while it was super cold, no flour, egg mix, breadcrumbs, egg mix more breadcrumbs and did the sides first before I did the large surface areas. They turned out brilliantly.
It was my wife's birthday and she loves warm Goat’s Cheese Salad. I am not a fan but this occasion deserved an effort, which you have luckyly accompanied, Nagi. (another) big THANK YOU.
When your lunch guests ask you for the recipe you know its good!  Thanks Nagi!

Nagi, I made this salad for dinner tonight and it is hands down one of the best salads I’ve ever had. Much to my delight, I was able to find ripened goat cheese at my local supermarket! While this made the salad, my husband and I both thought the rest of the salad was quite tasty on its own. I will definitely be making this again!

Also, you look fabulous!!!!
I had a feeling it was Duck Confit but the rest of the party always had the Beef Bourguignon so I was doubting myself. It looks delicious.  I can’t wait for another international week.
